content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: People will enjoy it and the solution is easy.

typo: BDC -> BCD
"millisecond" digit -> tenth of second digit (as already commented below)
Otherwise fine for me.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's fine.  Could be a clash.  Took two lines of code in C#.

Please change "millisecond"/"milliseconds" to "tenths of a second" (or "deciseconds" if we're in the mood). The only way the milliseconds value can be a single digit is if every input time occurs in the first 0.01s of the given second.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is fun to code
I coded my solution in Python, it was fun. not sure why there is a loop 4 in stub (4 lines in output?)

Goal
* Please remove the detailed description of GDQ, and include a link instead (like you do for BDC).

Input
* Please delete the example, as an example has been shown in Example section.

* Suggest to merge the Input description and the constraint as follows:
<<Line 1>>: A string [[Input]] containing the current time to display. It is in the 24-hour time format of [[HH]]{{:}}[[MM]]{{:}}[[SS]]{{:}}[[s]], where [[HH]] (hours), [[MM]] (minutes), [[SS]] (seconds) are shown as 2 digits and [[s]] (milliseconds) is shown as a single digit.

Output / Cases / Goal
* In the last line, please format "H", "M", "S" and "s" as [[variables]].

* Why is the format HMMSSs in the output? What if [[HH]] in the original input time is 10 or more? Such cases should be added.

* Please move everything from "Each digit will be displayed" to the last line of Output section to Goal section.

Constraints
* After the above changes, please delete the constraint.

Thanks.

Most of the changes have been made.

"Why is the format HMMSSs in the output? What if [[HH]] in the original input time is 10 or more? Such cases should be added."

This is a constraint of the original clock displayed on GDQ streams. As far as I can tell, this clock only displays 6 digits. I just looked up what is probably their source code, and it looks like the original code also does not roll over.

I could change the inputs to single digit for hours, and my demo code should already support it. But I feel there's a bit more challenge working with the three types of input/output combinations. XX->Y, XX->YY, X->Y.

If it's a big issue, I can just change the inputs to match the output, though.

Ah. Yes, that's what I was thinking. But my test code buffers all the text and then writes it all at once.

I quickly rewrote the code to test if it works with individual console writes. Everything works fine there. Thanks for bringing that up!
Thanks! Glad you enjoyed.

I had initially ignored this, as it seemed more intuitive to use milliseconds to describe that digit. If this is actually an issue, I can change it to something more appropriate. In C#, that digit was referenced as 'f'. So if it would be more appropriate to call is a fractional digit, I can make these changes:

"We need to display 1 hour digit, 2 minute digits, 2 second digits, and 1 fractional digit."

"It is in the 24-hour time format of [[HH]]{{:}}[[MM]]{{:}}[[SS]]{{:}}[[f]], where [[HH]] (hours), [[MM]] (minutes), [[SS]] (seconds) are shown as 2 digits and [[f]] (fractional) is shown as a single digit."

"These lines will be in the format:
 {{|}}[[H]]{{|}}[[M]]{{|}}[[M]]{{|}}[[S]]{{|}}[[S]]{{|}}[[f]]{{|}}"
:O I'd love to see that! I think it's a little complex for a clash. Maybe I'm just inexperienced and coding it completely wrong, though. Thanks for the approval.

I had initially ignored this issue with the milliseconds as it seemed more intuitive to me to state it as milliseconds. But if this is actually an issue, I can change it. Since, at least in C#, that digit is known as 'f' I propose these changes, if that sounds fine:

"We need to display 1 hour digit, 2 minute digits, 2 second digits, and 1 fractional digit."

"It is in the 24-hour time format of [[HH]]{{:}}[[MM]]{{:}}[[SS]]{{:}}[[f]], where [[HH]] (hours), [[MM]] (minutes), [[SS]] (seconds) are shown as 2 digits and [[f]] (fractional) is shown as a single digit."

"These lines will be in the format:
 {{|}}[[H]]{{|}}[[M]]{{|}}[[M]]{{|}}[[S]]{{|}}[[S]]{{|}}[[f]]{{|}}"
And next time would you please read other people's comments and make sure all of them have been addressed before you approve a contribution. Thank you.
Ok I will next time thank you this is my first time so I don't know.

If it's still possible to fix the errors, I will gladly do that. I've not made a contribution before, so I'm not sure if that's an option.

The BCD typo is definitely an issue, I would like to fix that.

The Milliseconds/Deciseconds argument seems minor to me. But if that's actually something people are considering incorrect, I can change it. Technically, the code to get time in C# used F as the designation for that digit, so I assume it is meaning fractional or something similar. If that's actually an issue for people I will change it to something more appropriate.

I am willing to change the texts to the following:
"We need to display 1 hour digit, 2 minute digits, 2 second digits, and 1 fractional digit."

"It is in the 24-hour time format of [[HH]]{{:}}[[MM]]{{:}}[[SS]]{{:}}[[f]], where [[HH]] (hours), [[MM]] (minutes), [[SS]] (seconds) are shown as 2 digits and [[f]] (fractional) is shown as a single digit."

"These lines will be in the format:
 {{|}}[[H]]{{|}}[[M]]{{|}}[[M]]{{|}}[[S]]{{|}}[[S]]{{|}}[[f]]{{|}}"

Thank you for your explanation and the changes made.

Goal
* Please change "it's" to "its".

* Please change "Each Digit" to "Each digit".

Input
* Please change "HH:MM:SS:s" to "[[HH]]{{:}}[[MM]]{{:}}[[SS]]{{:}}[[s]]".

The issue of not having HH ≥ 10
* If the clock displays 7 digits as per your comment, and if those 7 digits refer to HH:MM:SS:s, then you *can* include cases where HH ≥ 10, because the current output format consists of 6 digits only. So, I think there are two alternatives:

(a) Leave the cases as is, but add a constraint: 00 ≤ [[HH]] ≤ 09.

(b) Change the output format to display 7 digits, change the expected output of all the existing cases, and add cases where HH ≥ 10.

Thanks.

Sorry, that was a typo on my part. The original clock is 6 segments, not 7. I have added the constraint to HH.

Typos fixed.

Input is already set to "[[HH]]{{:}}[[MM]]{{:}}[[SS]]{{:}}[[s]]". It's just hard to see the blue on the ':', but browser tools do show the "<const>" tag on the HTML.

Ah, ok. I think there was a lag in the update to the CodinGame's database, and that's why I thought that wasn't updated yet. All right now.

Thank you again.
All good. Thanks for the suggestions!
